results.notes:
Growing on the side of a Quercus log. Associated with a white rot. Quercus alba, Carya spp., Fagus grandifolia and Acer saccharum nearby. Whispy rhizomorphs present at the margins. Hymenium fragile. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamps. Some septa ampullate. Encrusted hyphoid leptocystidia present. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores warted and hyaline. Spore measurements: (3.2) 3.5 – 4.1 (4.3) × (2.6) 2.8 – 3.2 µm, Q = (1.1) 1.15 – 1.4 (1.6); N = 30, Me = 3.8 × 3 µm; Qe = 1.3

results.notes: This organism grows every year, like clockwork, around the same time (2nd half of June) on a lawn under a majestic scarlet oak. These rarely reach maturity, as they are either quickly eaten by squirrels or get blasted by the afternoon sun. When young, the unexpanded caps are dark brown, with much lighter margins. At maturity they are totally gray. This exemplar had the cap color between the two extremes — olive-brown gray disk and gray margins.

results.notes:
Found along Wright’s Lake Road in bloom at the edge of mixed conifer forest.
Mycoheterotrophic plants with dark-red stem and no green (chlorophyll). Flowers opposite to alternate, with 5 petals. Petals pure white at first, becoming pink-shaded over time and becoming more downward-facing. Pistils/anthers creamy to pale yellow. The flower shape is rather campanulate and distinctive, especially among plants here that are fungal parasites.
Compared with Pterospora (pinedrops), they were generally smaller with smaller inflorescences and Pterospora has prominent vinaceous sepals, which these lacked, as well as a more heath-shaped flower (never quite so broadly open as these). Allotropa (candystick or sugarstick) has a distinct candy-cane (red-and-white striped) stem, and more of the opposite combination with white sepals and red flowers. Sarcodes (snowplant) and Monotropa have a completely different appearance, and Corallorhiza (coralroot) can be eliminated as they are orchids.
This species has a widespread distribution in the mountains and coastal forests of Northern California, but is generally uncommon, at least in the central and southern Sierra Nevada.

results.notes:
Megacollybia rodmanii form murina
St. Croix State Park (Hinckley, MN)
06/20/2020

-Habitat: In conifer/pine section of mixed woods featuring oak, maple and aspen.
- Habit: Small cluster growing on one spot.
- Substrate: Most likely attached to buried wood beneath duff, but was growing in close proximity to decaying fish skins from eagle/fisherman. Sandy soil

-Cap: Gray with striations at margin. Conical, bursting at the top (a tear maybe grok insect or rapid growth?). Lots of larvae appearing on cap. Becoming more flat. 45-60mm length.
- Stem: White. Smooth. More or less equal
50-70mm length. 4 mm width. With rooting base. No ring.
- Gills: White. Attached/barely attached to stem. 10 mm height, 33 mm long). Close, but not crowded.
- Spore print: White
results.location_name: St. Croix State Park, Pine Co., Minnesota, USA

results.notes: Was trying to do a time lapse of these but greedy rodents stole all of them last night. Found under a spruce tree growing off roots. Caps are orange 3-5" in diameter. Covered in yellow faded white warts. Some are striking globular. Almost perfect. Stipe is white 3-6" long tapering to a bulbous base. Stipe has a ring as well as brownish hairy Chevron styled conscentric pattern. Spore print of ones I had is white confirming amanita to species. Growing in a half fairy ring containing 12 specimens over a 15’ area. Sweet mushrooms odor. I could smell them before I seen them. Gills are white and crowded.

Pholiota subsulphurea
St. Croix State Park (Hinckley, MN)
06/20/2020

- Habitat: Mixed woods with conifer, oak, aspen and maple present.
- Habit: Growing in small clusters.
- Substrate: Decaying log

- Cap: 12-24mm. Hemispherical to nearly flat. Orangish-yellow color. Covered in tiny scales. Remnants hanging over cap edge. Flesh=white with tinge of yellow.
- Stem: 25-45mm length (3-4mm width). More or less equal. Sometimes fusing two specimens together. Yellow with barely attached white fibrils.
- Gills: Close, golden/yellow. Attached to stem.
- Spore print: Dark brown

Neolentinus lepideus (The Train Wrecker)
St. Croix State Park (Hinckley, MN)
06/20/2020

- Habitat: Mixed woods with conifer, oak, aspen and maple present.
- Habit: Growing in pairs or alone.
- Substrate: Appearing to grow from log

- Cap: 58-70mm. Becoming flat, but slightly overlapping/uneven. Fibrils in a pattern similar to Pheasant back radiating from center that are light brown. Cap dingy yellow/light tan.
- Gills: White, but becoming yellow at margin. Jagged edges. Attached and close.
- Stem: More or less equal, but wider at base. Whitish/tan color with brown peeling fibers. Stuffed.
- Spore print: White

results.notes:
In moss.
As seen in photos, gill color ranges from white to very light brownish.
Spore print white (for both white-gilled and brown-gilled ones).
Spores not reactive in Meltzers, 6-7.5 × 5-6, covered in thin spines/warts seen in Congo red mount. When mounted in Meltzers, the spines were not seen.
No hymenial cystidia found.

I had thought Mycena for these. But the non-amyloid warty spores seem to point away from Mycena. Microscopy supports there being only one species here (younger white-gilled and more mature brownish-gilled).

results.notes:
Two single fruiting bodies growing amongst old mulch, poor soil and some grass/weeds.
Macro:
Pileus about 1.5 cm broad, whitish with vinaceous-purple fibrils at disc, whitish fibrils elsewhere, yellowing when handled/damaged and also yellowing in age; Lamellae whitish when young, becoming greyish purple, edges remaining whitish, finally dark brown to nearly black and edges becoming concolorous; Stipe ~ 4 cm in length, 0.3 – 0.4 mm wide, white to off-white, essentially equal with slightly enlarged base, tomentose, yellowing immediately upon handling, resolving to golden-orange; Annulus tomentose on upper surface, yellowing like the rest of the mushroom, fragile, friable; Odor/Taste smell nondistinctive to somewhat sweet & pleasant, did not taste.

Chemical Tests:
KOH immediately yellow on all parts (did not apply to gills).

Micro:
TBD

results.notes:
Growing near a large hemlock.
About 8 in hes wide, 6 inches high.
Same location (~100 square yards) as in 2017 obs 279638. For obs 279638 I had written that several vertically aligned fruit bodies were growing near large oaks. The one seein this observation was next to a large hemlock, and I think at least one seen in 279638 is near the same hemlock. I don’t think this is B. berkeleyi. I would expect that by July a B. berkeleyi fruit body would show more of the typical shleflike form. I cut off sample but lost it when I later dropped the container of specimens.
The specimen seen here reminds me somewhat of Abortiporus biennis, except the context is very tough; a knife does not easily pass through the fruit body.

results.notes:

Tubes 1.5 cm deep max.

Staining as seen in photos. Bruise on pores pinkish at first transitioning to almost black. Context white, staining pinkish tan in the stipe and lower cap with a slightly purplish tinge in lower part of cap. Upper part of cap context staining light blue (a feature not mentioned in any source I have consulted up to this point in time). Over time, the staining intensified and resolved dark brown to almost black (IGS).
Taste mild. Odor pleasant (with a slight cinnamon note).
Spores not fusoid (a few favorably aligned appearing slightly subfusoid). Spores mainly long-elliptic 7.5-10 × 3.4-4.5.

results.notes:
A single withering basidiocarp growing in leaf litter in a small stand of beech trees (oak and other hardwoods farther away) near the trail running along the creek.
The fruitbody was 12 cm tall; the saccate volva was 4 cm tall from the base to the longest limb. The pileal and stipital context reddened immediately upon longitudinal sectioning. The unexpanded cap showed a clear sign of dehydration (wrinkly cuticle, dark gills). I didn’t expect it to drop spores, so it was sampled for DNA (CTAB buffer) and dried immediately.
DNA Results and Discussion (posted on 9-Feb-21; last edited 27-Mar-23):
> A contiguous nrLSU sequence of 1393 bps was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from two forward reads (LR0R and LR3R) and posted to this observation. The reads have a bit of common overlap in the middle to give the so called “joined contig”. The sequence becomes legible from just before the ITS6R primer area and goes all the way to the LR7 primer (the 3’ end of the PCR amplicon), which was seen and edited out. Unlike it’s often the case with ITS, it’s not possible to get a consensus sequence for LSU with just two reads due to the length of the span from the start of the locus to the LR7 primer area. All reads eventually start losing resolution after 600 bps, and sometimes sooner, which is the nature of the beast. However, if the reads are of good quality, joined contigs are a perfectly satisfactory result.
The long LR0R read had to be worked on because the sequence quickly became heteromorphic. Fortunately, it was possible to confidently resolve the two haplotypes to the point where the LR3R read picked up (as a single set of peaks, naturally). However, there were 4 positions represented by triple peaks that couldn’t be resolved, as they likely represented ambiguous sites in both haplotypes. A reverse read from LR5 might be helpful to confirm or even resolve these ambiguities, but is unnecessary considering that the sequence leads to a good ID.
> A BLASTn search of the first 911 bases, which represents the most commonly sequenced region of nrLSU (from start to the LR5 primer area) gave Rod Tulloss’ 11 accessions of Amanita whetstoneae as top hits at 98.8-99.6% similarity. The only mismatching positions for two of these were the 4 aforementioned ambiguities. I think this constitutes a pretty conclusive ID.

results.notes:
A group of four mature fruiting bodies growing on a steep hill under beech trees, with oaks and a single hickory nearby. This collection came from the same general location, if not the same exact spot, as obs 244111 (collected 4 years ago), which is undoubtedly the same species/organism based on the overall macromorphology. Three of the four basidiomata were collected and preserved; fresh tissue was also sampled in CTAB buffer.
Caps 5.5-6.6 cm wide across the surface; cap flesh 1-1.2 cm thick above the stipe, yellowish, bluing very slowly and faintly just above the tubes and at the stipe juncture. Tubes 7-10 mm deep, not bluing when cut; pore surface irregular, bluing quickly but faintly upon injury; pores angular, 1-2 per mm. Stipes straight to curved, 4.5-6.6 cm long, flaring at the apex, fairly equal below and generally 5-7 mm wide; stipe flesh concolorous with cap flesh. Odor slightly farinaceous; flesh not tasted.
KOH on cap cuticle = deep reddish-brown. NH4OH on cap cuticle = blue-green flash, brown under the liquid drop, bluish around the drop circumference.

Overall, this species seems to be a good fit for A. psedovolvata. The only main difference I noticed was the infrequent/rare lamellulae. Compare with the similar-looking but larger obs 370560 and obs 373977 – both collected in the same general area and close to each other, but at some distance away (30-50 yards) from this post. The former of the earlier observations was sequenced (LSU, results yet to be disclosed/discussed).

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

2014-2020, Registros
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/...
2016, Publicación
https://www.researchgate.net/...
2020, Recopilación
https://mushroomobserver.org/414059?q=1JArw

A continuación, se realiza su respectiva descripción: basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, píleo de 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse con el tiempo, con escamas blancas y fasciculadas en el margen, originadas por restos del velo universal. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, de superficie pruinosa. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. En algunos ejemplares se logra observar un anillo en banda (rudimentario) adherido al estípite, delgado y efimero. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

El trabajo de microscopia se realizó con un Microscopio Zeiss de Luz Halogena 6v 30w y reactivos rojo congo, melzer e hidróxido de potasio (KOH) 5%. Se observan basidios tetraspóricos, claviformes de 31 × 8 µm, basidiosporas elipsoidales no amiloides, de color marrón a rojo oscuro, superficie lisa, ligeramente apiculadas, con poro germinativo evidente (0,8 a 1 µm). Cistidios fusiformes, de 35,7 × 12,7 µm en general se observan hifas paralelas y presencia de fíbulas.

results.notes:
Actually I found this several years ago. At 6000 feet, on subalpine habitat with a short summer season. With a tree mix of subalpine spruce and fir.
I didn’t know what it was then and I have keep the pictures for years, but I remember some details fairly well:
Feels like a handball in your hand, of very light weight, and spongy. Cap dry, velvety, with the margin upturned, the cap cuticle feels thin, with a reddish tone. The pores decurrent red also, elongated.
No color change to blue, maybe to red, and the velvety cap should define the species.
Now I now what to look for. Maybe I will obtain some spores, in another find soon.

results.notes:
Posee basidiomas que son bastante fáciles de identificar, ya que forman grupos bastante densos. El sombrero es pequeño, de 1 a 2 cm, acampanado, ovoide o cónico, con una pubescencia formada por pelos erectos y obtusos e incoloros; su color es gris amarillento con tonalidades pardas. Bajo este sombrero está el himenio, formado por láminas distantes, libres, de color gris a negruzco.

Estos ejemplares fueron encontrados sobre tocones de Pinus radiata.
results.location_name: Lebu, Biobio Region, Chile

results.notes: Found in mulch in a planter on the street. At first site I thought it was eps foam and then I noticed the larger bodies. Interestingly, the body seems to grow in a soft expansion and then harden off. This can be seen by the leaf imprints and the trapped leaves in the cross-section. Sometimes it feels like you can’t do anything without running in to some fungi you feel compelled to document.

results.notes:
Ejemplar con forma de coral muy ramificado, de 10 a 20 cm de altura y de 8 a 15 cm de anchura, de color blanco amarillento o amarillo azufre; tiene un tronco grueso y carnoso del que parten ramas más o menos largas, cilíndricas que se van dividiendo varias veces hasta terminar en varias puntas obtusas.

Base de forma variable, de color amarillo blanquecino, muy ramificado, con ramas y puntas amarillo azufre uniforme que pasan al crema ocráceo al madurar las esporas. Himenio liso o débilmente rugoso que cubre toda la superficie de las ramas.

Este ejemplar fue encontrado bajo bosque dominado por Nothofagus obliqua.

Es un hongo comestible poco conocido asociado obligatoriamente a

especies de Nothofagus spp. Presenta un píleo de color café en el centro, más blanquecino por los bordes y un estípite liso de color blanco. Crece de manera cespitosa.

Estos ejemplares de encontraban creciendo en bosque dominado por Nothofagus alpina.

Suriname

results.notes:
Posee fructificaciones de gran tamaño (entre 15 – 30 cm de diámetro), con numerosos sombreros dispuestos unos sobre otros, como en repisa. De color blanco crema, con aspecto sucio, se encuentra tapizado por poros decurrentes de color blanco crema orientados hacia el suelo. El estípite es de color blanco, rígido y excéntrico. Presenta carne muy delgada, de textura carnosa. Aroma y sabor almendrado.

Es una especie degradadora de madera, a la que le provoca una pudrición blanca alveolar. Crece sobre ramas y fustes de árboles en pie o caídos, en lugares con baja cobertura arbórea.

El ejemplar de la fotografía estaba creciendo en tronco vivo de Nothofagus nitida.
results.location_name: Estación Biológica Senda Darwin, Chile

results.notes:
Es un hongo saprótrofo de sombrero blanco y pie amarillo que se oscurece hacia la base. Habita sobre ramas de Nothofagus obliqua, Drimys winteri y otras plantas leñosas.

Estos basidiomas se encontraban creciendo en pequeños grupos sobre ramas muertas de Nothofagus.
results.location_name: Cordillera de Nahuelbuta, Biobío Region, Chile

results.notes:
Posee fructificaciones ocres cuando es jóvenes, que se vuelven marrón con la edad, para diferenciar las especies de este género y del género Ramaria, es necesario un estudio microscópico para lograr su identificación.

Este ejemplar de P. flaccida fue encontrado bajo Aextoxicon punctatum.
